div.l: Yite in oure asshen olde fyre is Reken
Foure gledes haue we which I shall devise
A vauntyng lying anger and couetise
Thes foure sparkes longeth vnto Elde
Oure olde lymmes we mowe not welde
But yite it shall not faile that is sothe
And yite I haue all wey a coltes tothe
As many a yere as it is passed henne
Sithen that my tappe of lif began to renne
For sekerlyke when I was borne anoone
Dethe drewe the tappe of lif and lete it gone
And nowe so longe hath the tappe ronne
Till that all moste all Empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf nowe droppeth on the chymbe
This Cely tonge wele may rynge and chymbe
Of wrechednesse that passed is full yore
With olde folkes sauf dotage is no more
When that oure hoste hadde herde oure ʆsermonyng
He gan to speke as lordly as a kyng
And what seide he amounteth all this wit
What shall we speke all day of hooly writ
The devyll made a reve forto preche
Or of a Souter a shipman or a leche
Say forthe thy tale and tarye nought the tyme
Lo here is depforde and it is passed pryme
Lo grenewyche there many a shrewe is Inn̄
Yite were it tyme thy tale to be gynn̄
Nowe Sirs qduod this Oswolde the reve
I pray you all that noone of you greve
Though I answere somwhat to sette his houve
For lefull is with force force of shouve
This dronken myln̉er hath tolde vs here
Howe that begiled was a carpentere
Par auenture in scorne for I am oone
And be youre leve I shall hym quyte anoone
Right in his clerkes termes wil I speke
I pray to god his neck mote to breke
He can wele in myn Eye se a stalke
But in his owne Eye he can not se a balke
At trompyngton nought ferr͗e from cambrygge
There gothe a broke and oủer that a brygge
Vppon the which broke there stante a mylle
And this is verrey sothe that I you telle
